channel.title: üîé Forensic Investigation on Analyst
channel.description: Recent content in üîé Forensic Investigation on Analyst

item.title: Investigation Process üóíÔ∏è
item.description: The Anatomy Of Investigation Identification/Assessment. Understand your scope (technical and legal aspects), your goals and people you are going to work with.

item.title: Data Collection Checklist ü§è
item.description: Logical Backup - doesn’t copy all, doesn’t copy slack, free space and deleted files. Imaging - bit-by-bit copy.

item.title: Imaging ü§è
item.description: Logical Backup - doesn’t copy all, doesn’t copy slack, free space and deleted files. Imaging - bit-by-bit copy.

item.title: Confif Changes Analysis üîé
item.description: Can be hard (no consistency). Are they different by accident or from malicous intent. Baseline reference (what the settings should be).

item.title: Data Analysis Checklist üìù
item.description: First, have a template for an IR/forensics sheet. This can be done in Excel or other program alike.

item.title: Malware Analysis üîé
item.description: Signed executable. It’s a rare case, but it exists. Around 3% of malware is signed. It’s due to the fact that some systems require executables to be signed.

item.title: Network Traffic Analysis
item.description: Collection Most of the devices keep some sort of logs. As for the network related issues these are switches, routers, firewalls, IDS and IPS, web proxies, DC and authentication servers, DCHP server and application servers.

item.title: eDiscovery
item.description: eDiscovery Forensics and eDiscovery are very close terms, but not the same. eDiscovery is collecting all information and diciding whether this information is relevant for the investigation.

item.title: Browser Info
item.description: Many browsers are based on Chromium engine, that‚Äôs why they will have similar artifacts: Chrome, Opera, new Edge, Brave, Vivaldi.

item.title: Host and Network Logs
item.description: One of the most useful artifacts when properly configured and maintained, are log files. All devices keep some sort of logs, even mobile devices.

item.title: Mail üì¨
item.description: Outlook The main artifacts are stored in C:\Users\%USERNAME%\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Outlook. Get OST and PST files. Contains messages, contacts, calendars, notes.

item.title: Document Artefacts
item.description: There are several ways to determine file type: extension, signatures and structure. The most reliable is the last one, since extentsions can be easily changed and signatures are not very reliable (polymorphic files).

item.title: Account Information
item.description: Windows There are two main places within the registry that contains that information: SAM hive for local and Microsoft accounts and Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\ProfileList for Domain Accounts.

item.title: Recent Activity
item.description: Windows There are several artifacts indicating user activity. One of them is LNK files. To analyse acquired LNK files use üõ† LECmd (E.

item.title: Messaging Data ü§è
item.description: Electron is a framework that is available for building applications, cross-platform. You‚Äôre creating a web-application that can be used as a desktop one (implementing both back- and frontend).

item.title: Misc Artefacts
item.description: Devices Attached Windows Are we looking for USB storage media activity or all USB devices? Like, cameras üì∏?
